text: hundreds of scientists from around the
world are gathering in Geneva to try and
come up with a unified strategy on how
to fight the corona virus it comes as
Chinese officials say the corona virus
outbreak has now killed more than a
thousand people in total there are over
42,000 recorded cases and the exact
number of deaths caused by the virus now
stands at 1016 people in China while the
vast majority of cases are in mainland
China a total of 28 countries and
territories have recorded infections and
the effect on business is ongoing in
Asia 70 companies have pulled out of the
Singapore Air Show what came to show
that it is in control the government in
Beijing has removed several senior
officials over their handling of the
corona virus outbreak well let's go live
now to our two correspondents Imogen
Fuchs who is in Switzerland for us in
Geneva and in Beijing Steve McDonald
joins us and Imogen first of all to you
the w-h-o under huge pressure here to
prove that it really is working hard to
bring this virus under control that's
absolutely right and I think you know
having watched the waho officials over
the last two to three weeks they are
working really hard
nobody had a break this last weekend or
the weekend before in fact tracking the
progress of this virus they sent a team
to China there in daily contact with
Chinese health officials and with health
officials in neighboring countries
Singapore Hong Kong Taiwan so I think
yes but what they are really keen to do
is to make sure that they're doing
everything possible to contain this
virus to pull the knowledge that's what
all the scientists are doing here today
the available knowledge about it what
works in the treatment of it why it
spreads how it spreads and to check but
to do all that without causing over
anxiety over alarm things that could
cause countries to take measures which
might not necessarily be necessary and
could cause a
of particularly economic damage and
Stephen as Imogen was saying there a lot
of collaboration now between the w-h-o
and the Chinese authorities in fact WH o
landing in China yesterday and that's
pretty unusual isn't it for trying to be
so open with an organization like wh o
well I don't know if it's necessarily
unusual but what people are remembering
is the SARS outbreak when it took a long
time for Chinese officials to inform the
World Health Organization of that
outbreak now this time once the
Communist Party decided that this was a
major emergency the information has been
flowing much more freely though we've
had some pretty major developments here
today for example if you look at the
official statistics at the official
numbers rather those who've been
infected those who've died now sure
they're flawed they can't catch all of
the cases but if we if we consider it in
trend terms outside of who Bay province
it does seem to be going down I mean
it's a sort of squiggly line but the
trend over the last week has been a
downward one now if that bears out the
truth of the situation then it does seem
to show that these huge restrictions on
people's movements here are actually
kicking in and this is something that
the World Health Organization will be
wanting to speak to Chinese officials
when they come here to discuss the
possibility of what other restrictions
should be put in place to see if it's
working
I mean the other thing is that of course
if you consider the early days of this
outbreak there's a lot of anger here
that those precious early weeks were
lost and that's why you've seen these
first couple of senior officials
dismissed the party secretary and the
director of the who Bay provincial
health Commission they have gone but I
think people know this is you know
there's got a long way to go in terms of
people being dismissed because of this I
think lots more heads are going to roll
and image them back to you in Geneva of
course in Europe there there has been at
this concerted effort hasn't there and
the w-h-o director-general
about how there needs to be solidarity
but just talking about the dangers now
faced by European countries we've had
the the super spreader in the UK one guy
who is apparently spread the disease to
11 different people so the rate at which
it can grow is quite frightening well
it's not quite clear those those speeds
and how the virus is transmitted
interestingly I was talking to the
wuh-oh yesterday evening about this
concept of a super spreader with other
journalists and the w-h-o experts said
that UK individual would not be seen in
their classification as an actual super
spreader I think here again were on this
tightrope between doing the right thing
making sure every containment measure
possible is taken and not causing over
anxiety over alarm and I think fair
enough it's right that European
countries that's what the w-h-o is
saying of course they need to prepare
preparedness is something the w-h-o is
undermining all the time but you know
perspective as well at the moment it's
the winter flu season there are many
more people in Europe particularly the
elderly and the infirm at risk of winter
flu as things stand at the moment than
from the coronavirus and I think the EE
what the w-h-o probably would like to
see is countries preparing for the
winter flu really well every year
because preparations like that work just
as well against another virus washing
your hands not going to work when you're
sick using tissues when you sneeze or a
cough all of those things are what
people should be doing but try not to
worry too much
image and that's very very good
